concern: Iâ€™m feeling nervous about college and debating if iâ€™ve picked the right one. Iâ€™m already registered for classes and I have my dorm room/roomate all set but I canâ€™t help but feel nervous. Does/Did anyone feel this way? Iâ€™m very introverted and I feel like I wonâ€™t be able to make friends because Iâ€™m just awkward.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! I'm really glad you've reached out for support. Please take your time to share whatever's been on your mind or weighing on your heartâ€”I'm here to listen and help in any way I can. ðŸ’š
Hey, thanks for being here. Iâ€™m just feeling super nervous about starting college and whether I made the right choice, you know?

That sounds really tough. Itâ€™s totally normal to feel nervous when starting something new, especially something as big as college. I can imagine youâ€™re probably feeling a bit unsure about whether you made the right decision. Itâ€™s okay to feel that way, and it doesnâ€™t mean that you didnâ€™t make a good choice. It just means youâ€™re human, and you care about your future.
Yeah, exactly, I just keep second-guessing myself even though everythingâ€™s already set up. Itâ€™s like Iâ€™m worried I wonâ€™t fit in or something, and I donâ€™t know how to shake that feeling.

That's a really valid concern. Itâ€™s natural to worry about fitting in, especially when youâ€™re stepping into a new environment. Can you tell me more about whatâ€™s making you feel that way? What are some of the things that come to mind when you think about not fitting in?

Hey, yeah, I guess itâ€™s just that Iâ€™m super introverted and kinda awkward when it comes to meeting new people. I keep picturing myself just standing there not knowing what to say or how to connect with anyone.

That sounds really overwhelming. It's okay to feel awkward or nervous when meeting new people, especially if you're introverted. It's understandable that you're worried about fitting in, but it's important to remember that everyone feels that way at some point, even in new situations.
Yeah, I get that, but I still feel like Iâ€™m gonna be the only one struggling to figure this out. Itâ€™s just hard to imagine myself actually making friends when Iâ€™m so in my head about it.

It's understandable to feel that way, especially when your mind is racing with worries about the future. Have you thought about what your life might be like in a few months if you take small steps to connect with others, even if it's just one person at a time?

Yeah, I mean, Iâ€™ve tried to picture it, but itâ€™s hard to see past the nerves right now. I guess if I could just talk to one person and it goes okay, that might help, but Iâ€™m still kinda stuck on how to even start that.

It's okay to feel stuck right now, and it's great that you're open to the idea of taking small steps. Can we try to imagine that scenario where you connect with one person together? What would that look like, and what might help you feel more at ease in that moment?

Honestly, I think just picturing myself walking up to someone and saying hi feels so weird and forced. Iâ€™d probably be overthinking every word, but maybe if itâ€™s in a casual setting, like a class or club, itâ€™d feel less scary if I had something specific to talk about, you know?
It sounds like having a shared interest or activity could help ease some of that pressure. What kind of classes or clubs might you be interested in joining?

Iâ€™m not totally sure yet, but Iâ€™ve been thinking about maybe a book club or something related to my major since Iâ€™d at least have that in common with people. It just feels less intimidating if the conversation can start around something I already kinda know about, you know?

Based on your thoughts about a book club or something related to your major, those could be great options to start with. What do you think would be the first step in finding or joining one of those, and how might we make that feel a little less overwhelming?

I guess the first step would be looking up if thereâ€™s a book club or some group tied to my major on the school website or maybe asking around during orientation. It still feels kinda nerve-wracking to actually show up, so maybe just starting by checking online or writing down a couple questions to ask about the group could make it less daunting.

That's a great idea to start with something low-pressure, like checking online or preparing a few questions to ask. What do you think would help you feel more comfortable once you're actually at the event?

I think maybe just reminding myself that everyone there is probably looking to connect over the same interest could help me relax a bit. Also, having a plan to just listen at first, instead of jumping into talking, might make it feel less intense while I get a sense of the group.

therapist: That sounds like a solid plan to ease yourself into the group dynamic by focusing on listening and reminding yourself of shared interests. How about we check in next session to see how that first step of looking online or preparing questions goes?

client: Yeah, that sounds good to me. Iâ€™ll try to have an update for you by then, even if itâ€™s just a small step forward.
